content: The Act titled "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation property under section 25E of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. The credit allows 25% of the expenditures, not exceeding $5,000 per year, for specific property improvements to mitigate hurricane and tornado damage. The Act "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" offers a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. This includes improvements such as preventing water intrusion, improving roof durability, bracing gable-end walls, reinforcing roof-wall connections, protecting against windborne debris, and safeguarding doors and garages in qualified dwelling units located in specific states. The Act "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" provides a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures in specific states. Expenditures must be approved by a State-certified inspector for onsite preparation, assembly, or installation to be eligible. Labor costs related to these activities are also considered for the credit. The Act allows for a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures in specific states. Expenditures must be approved by a State-certified inspector for onsite preparation, assembly, or installation to be eligible. Labor and inspection costs related to these activities are also considered for the credit. The Act introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures in certain states. The credit applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The Act introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures in certain states. The credit is 25% of qualified expenditures, not exceeding $5,000 per year. Qualified expenditures include improving roof strength, creating water barriers, enhancing roof durability, bracing walls, reinforcing roof connections, and protecting openings from debris. The Act introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures in certain states. Qualified expenditures include improving roof strength, creating water barriers, enhancing roof durability, bracing walls, reinforcing roof connections, and protecting openings from debris. Qualified place of business refers to a location assessed at less than $5,000,000, and qualified states include Alabama, Arkansas, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Hawaii, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, and Minnesota. The credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures is limited to qualified states like Alabama, Arkansas, Colorado, etc. Expenditures must be approved by a State-certified inspector for onsite preparation, assembly, or installation to be considered. Labor costs related to these activities are also eligible for the credit. The curr_chunk discusses the allocation of labor and inspection costs for hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. Labor costs for onsite preparation, assembly, or installation are considered, as well as inspection costs related to the property. These expenditures are part of determining the qualified expenses for the taxpayer. The curr_chunk amends Section 38(b) of the tax code to include the hurricane and tornado mitigation credit. It also updates the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of the tax code. The curr_chunk introduces the "Hurricane and tornado mitigation credit" under Section 45O, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007.
